newsitem.title: FINLAND: Amer K owners say bound by Moyne deal.
newsitem.headline: Amer K owners say bound by Moyne deal.

text.p: Controlling owners of sporting goods group Amer-yhtyma Oy said on Friday they are bound by an agreement with British investor Jonathan Bryan Guinness to not negotiate with others on a possible sale of their K-shares.
Four associations, which hold 90.5 percent of Amer's votes mainly through the K shares, agreed on June 2 to sell 1.1 million K shares to Guinness, third Lord Moyne, for 301 million markka.
This was rivalled on Thursday by Finnish investment company Norvestia, which said it was interested in bidding for part of the K shares at mainly the same terms as Guinness.

"According to our agreement (with Guinness), we will not negotiate with anyone else," Leea Murtolehto, chairman of the Finnish Association of Graduates in Economics and Business Administration (SEFE), told Reuters by telephone.

The Finnish Association of Graduate Engineers, the Student Union of the Helsinki School of Economics and Business Administration, SEFE and The Land and Water Foundation -- together own 1.99 million K shares. SEFE owns 25 percent of this.
Heikki Kauppi, secretary general of the engineers' association which ows 34 percent of K shares, said Norvestia could not do anything to sweeten the offer.
"Even if incomprehensible amounts of money had been offered, we would not be in a position to consider it," he said.

The agreement with Moyne involves lifting the listed A shares' voting power to 43 percent from only 10 percent currently, which would leave Guinness with 58 percent of votes and 4.6 percent of shares.
The four associations also own 748,835 listed A shares, giving them 11.5 percent of Amer's capital.
In all, the listed A shares represent 92 percent of capital, and they have preferential dividend rights.
Norvestia said its interest in making an offer would require that Amer used its right to redeem K shares, and this decision would be made by Amer's supervisory board.
"We intend to act (on the supervisory board) so that no redemption will happen," Murtolehto said.
